Descrip:
在病区内主要由病株残体上的子囊孢子通过气流传播先侵染花部，在发病季节，大量分生孢子通过雨水飞溅传播，栽种密集时，可通过相互接触直接传播到附近植株上。另外露水、雾滴、携带分生孢子的昆虫、气流也起一定传播作用。
远距离传播主要是通过带菌的插条、切花、种子的调运。
ICodeName: 一种危险性病害——菊花疫病

cankao.Publisher: 农牧渔业部植物检疫实验所
cankao.Title: 一种危险性病害——菊花疫病

ICodeName: 一种危险性病害——菊花疫病
ManagementInfo: 此病是菊花生产上的一个重要病害，尤其在欧洲各菊花产区。因病菌在整个菊花生长季节都表现很强的生活力与致病性，因此一般措施难以控制此病的发生。病菌一旦立足，就很难将其根除。1962年联邦德国颁布的植物检疫条令，就规定菊花疫病为检疫对象，1972年民主德国将之列为内检对象，以防止病害的进一步扩散。此病也是苏联、挪威的检疫对象。一旦发现病区，应将病区内的病株全部烧毁或腐烂，并对曾栽种过发病菊花苗的土壤进行严格消毒，可用三氯硝基甲烷（氯化苦）或蒸气灭菌处理。

cankao.Publisher: 农牧渔业部植物检疫实验所
cankao.Title: 一种危险性病害——菊花疫病

Descrip:
自然扩散通过食用果实的鸟和蝙蝠，也可通过水流、土壤等传播。人为传播通过引种、农作物的调运。
长距离传播主要通过园艺贸易。植株本地扩散通过种子，它的种子依靠食用果实的鸟和蝙蝠，也可能通过车辆或污染土壤。
ICodeName: 中国进境植物检疫性有害生物——杂草卷
ManagementInfo:
（1）物理方法：由于刺茄很难根除，因此新的分布地应尽早进行控制，防止进一步扩散。当小范围发生时可使用清除的方法，由于植株多刺，需注意安全。但根据巴布亚新几内亚的调查，机械控制方法（切断或拔除）不像化学方法那样有效。
（2）化学方法：可使用草甘膦进行处理。幼株（主茎基部直径0.5~1.0mm）也可使用50%的2,4-二氯苯氧乙酸丁酯（2,4-D丁酯）每亩50~70ml进行叶面喷洒，而成株（主茎基部直径1~6cm）和老的植株（主茎基部直径大于6cm），清除植株的上半部分，留下高度为10~15cm的草桩使用2,4,5-涕酸丁酯（2,4,5-T butyl ester）0.5%~1.0%水溶液喷洒可控制蔓延。
（3）其他方法：在美国夏威夷州发现，该物种的传播与来自分布区的设备或土壤有关。因此，对来自分布区的车辆和设备进行清洗有助于减少在毛伊岛的蔓延。
PotentialEcoDesc:
刺茄为多刺的灌木，常分布于热带和亚热带地区，耐干旱，在温暖湿润的肥沃条件下生长最好，生境包括：灌木林、森林空旷地，岩石山坡，牧场，沼泽，路边，废弃地等。高1~3m，有时可达5m，传入美国佛罗里达州后，在牧场形成密集灌木丛。植株具刺，易形成密集的单一物种，侵占林地、牧场，影响生态环境和林木业生产。
刺茄是美国有害杂草。目前已普遍定植在毛伊岛（夏威夷群岛中的第二大岛），主要归化于牧场和农业区低洼的干扰地，在夏威夷州发现它是地中海实蝇的寄主之一。
该物种的根和叶片产生3-氨基螺旋甾碱烷组（3-amino-spirosolane group）的类固醇生物碱。叶片、果实和根的主要成分为非生物碱以及生物碱和皂苷。根含圆锥茄次碱（jurubidine），是一种3-氨基螺旋甾碱烷（3-amino-spirosolane）的生物碱。在印度将其成熟果实作为蔬菜食用。在加纳它的果实用于做汤和炖煮。在印度和缅甸等国家种植，将其浆果用作调味，在斯里兰卡种子已被用于制作咖喱粉。在印度刺茄可以单独或其他药用植物组合使用，浆果用于治疗胸痛，叶片用于治疗蛇和昆虫的叮咬，果实和根治疗胃痛，根用于解毒，树皮用于治疗疟疾，浆果还能治疗夜盲症和牙齿感染。Lu（1986）记载，在中国发现该物种的根含生物碱，可用于散淤血，缓解疼痛，减轻咳嗽。果实具祛痰和止痛的功效。刺茄和茄子间作可用于抗假单胞菌、根结线虫属、轮枝菌属、根串珠霉属烟草黑胫病菌、疫霉菌和茄镰刀菌复合体。它还能抗茄二十八星瓢虫，但对炭疽病菌易感。

cankao.Title: 中国进境植物检疫性有害生物——杂草卷

PBCharHostRange: As a perennial species, S. torvum is unable to survive to maturity in annual crops and, as such, is most commonly a weed in perennial crops. In pastures it can be a major nuisance as it is woody, prickly and probably both unpalatable and poisonous. It is
PotentialEcoDesc: S. torvum is an invasive weed of pastures, roadsides and open native vegetation, and is occasionally found in cassava and other perennial crops in which it is not exposed to cultivation. It has been suggested that the plants are poisonous to stock, but no conclusive evidence is available.^p^pS. torvum is relatively resistant to Meloidogyne spp., and is used as a rootstock for grafting tomatoes in susceptible areas (Shetty and Reddy, 1985). It is also resistant to Pseudomonas solanacearum (Hebert, 1985) and phomopsis fruit rot of aubergine (Datar and Ashtaputre, 1988).^p^pThe species is a natural host for many insects and pathogens (see Natural Enemies section).

ManagementInfo: Cultural Control^p^pSeedlings may be hand pulled when the soil is wet, otherwise the plants need to be dug or grubbed out to remove the upper root from the soil either by hand or mechanical cultivation.^p^pChemical Control^p^pSeedlings can be controlled in pasture with 2,4-D (Henty and Pritchard, 1975; Chadhokar, 1976). Australian registrations for the control of S. torvum are restricted to 2,4-D + picloram (Hamilton, 1997).^p^pBiological Control^p^pNo work has been attempted to establish biological control agents for S. torvum, since it is too closely related to many useful crops and ornamentals.

PBCharHostRange: D. abyssinica is a weed of many crops, including large- and small-grain cereals, fibres (cotton, flax and sisal), tree crops (coffee, forestry nurseries, tea and wattle) and plantation crops including pineapple, pyrethrum and sugarcane.
PotentialEcoDesc: D. abyssinica is the most troublesome weed in the crops of Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania (Ivens, 1989). It is reported as the most important weed of coffee in Kenya and of cotton in Uganda (Holm et al., 1977). The growth and yield of crops is greatly reduced in the presence of D. abyssinica. Heavy infestations can kill coffee bushes (Ivens, 1989), reduce sisal yields by 2 t/ha (Richardson, 1965) and cotton yields by 50% (Prentice, 1957). This may be caused, in part, by toxins released from the roots of D. abyssinica which have an allelopathic effect on the crop (Wallis, 1959). Serious mechanical damage can occur when trying to remove rhizomes entwined in crop roots.

ManagementInfo: Mechanical Control^p^pA forked hoe will remove many rhizomes, however, this method is very labour intensive and total eradication of all viable fragments left in the soil is virtually impossible (Terry, 1974). Where high densities of D. abyssinica are present, ploughing with draught animals is impeded. The increased traction can cause injury to the shoulders of draught animals. Mechanical tillage with tractors can expose rhizomes to desiccation on the soil surface, but can also spread the fragmented rhizomes. In laboratory conditions, desiccation of rhizomes for four days at temperatures of 7°C to 27°C led to complete kill (Mshiu, 1978). Field trials with cover crops have shown that noug (Guizotia abyssinica) and linseed (Linum usitatissimum) considerably suppress D. abyssinica in coffee with no significant effect on the crop (Dubale, 1987). Rotation with noug (Guizota abyssinica) is also regarded as a useful control measure in Ethiopia.^p^pChemical Control^p^pHerbicides that have been tested and used against D. abyssinica include alloxydim, amitrole, asulam, butylate, dalapon, glufosinate-ammonium, glyphosate, haloxyfop, hexazinone, metribuzin, MSMA, sethoxydim, sulfosate (glyphosate-trimesium) and TCA - sodium. Dalapon was a standard treatment to young foliage (Ivens, 1989) but this has largely been superseded by glyphosate (Terry, 1974; Baguma et al., 1995).

PotentialEcoDesc: CoRSV is present in the main coffee-growing states of Brazil. The disease has not been of major importance since 1938 when it was first detected. However, in important coffee-growing regions of Minas Gerais State, 80-100% plantations were affected with this disease resulting in 20% yield losses (Figueira, 1995). The severity of the disease was attributed to ecological disturbances associated with expanding coffee areas and chemical pest control favouring the vector. Mutation of the virus is another possibility (Figueira, 1995).

Descrip: Incidence^p^pIn the Philippines, Reyes (1961) reported 8.7% seed transmission in Coffea excelsa [C. liberica] and Valdez (1966) found 16.9% in C. liberica and 25.7% in C. arabica.^p^pPathogen Transmission^p^pIn the Philippines, Reyes (1961) reported 8.7% seed transmission in C. excelsa [C. liberica] and Valdez (1966) found 16.9% in C. excelsa [C. liberica] and 25.7% in C. arabica. Nevertheless, seed transmission in Brazil proved negative; of 1149 C. arabica seedlings from affected coffee berries, none showed symptoms 18 months after sowing (Chagas, 1978). This confirmed what Silberschmidt and Bitancourt (1965) had reported previously in Brazil that the disease was not seedborne.

Remark: RISK CRITERIA 		CATEGORY^p^pECONOMIC IMPORTANCE	Low^pDISTRIBUTION		Philippines, Brazil, Costa Rica^pSEEDBORNE INCIDENCE	Disputed^pSEED TRANSMITTED	No^pSEED TREATMENT	None^p
